Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: SusChem: Organocatalysis: A Platform for Sustainable Polymer Chemistry
Award.AbstractNarration:
Polymers are highly useful modern materials for clothes, furniture, electronic devices, household products and appliances, food packages, and medicine. Polymer properties are controlled by the chemical structures of its building blocks. The preparation of polymers with new or improved properties requires the use of new blocking blocks, and the economical manufacturing of these polymers requires the development of efficient synthetic approaches to link the new building blocks together. In this project, Professor Robert Waymouth of Stanford University and Dr. James Hedrick of IBM Almaden Laboratories are developing a broad and versatile platform of methods to enable the synthesis of new building blocks and well-defined biodegradable polymers with novel structures, properties and function. This project provides a model academic / industrial collaboration between Stanford and IBM Almaden Laboratories under the auspices of NSF's GOALI program (Grant Opportunities for Academic Liason with Industry). It engages graduate students and postdoctoral scholars in a highly interdisciplinary and collaborative effort. The unusual educational environment embraces both academic and industrial perspectives on the translation of basic science into technology.

This project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the Chemistry Division focuses on the simultaneous development of new science and technologies. Specifically, this project aims to develop 1) new organocatalysts that are active and selective for ring-opening polymerization, 2) new strategies for the synthesis of new monomers (functionalized lactones and cyclic carbonates) that can be enchained to elicit novel properties and function for macromolecular materials, 3) a novel depolymerization reaction; and 4) new classes of "smart" water-soluble copolymers whose structures and properties can be modulated by changes in external environment. Central to the scientific approach is an emphasis on mechanistic and theoretical investigations to illuminate the mechanistic details of organocatalytic polymerization reactions, both to test evolving hypotheses on organocatalytic strategies and to provide clear scientific rationales for both the advantages and limitations of these synthetic strategies.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this proposal by Professor Robert M. Waymouth of Stanford University and Dr. James L. Hedrick of IBM Almaden was to to develop a versatile platform of synthetic methods based on organic catalysts to enable the synthesis of well-defined biodegradable macromolecules with novel structures, properties and function.. This collaborative program with Dr. James Hedrick of IBM Almaden laboratories was funded under the GOALI (Grant Opportunities for Academic Liason with Industry) mechanism through the Macromolecular / Supramolecular / Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division (CHE-1607092). The scientific objectives were closely integrated with training and education.  In the course of this project, students were able to acquire the intellectual and experimental expertise to address a broad range of research challenges in catalysis, polymer synthesis, the development of continuous flow reactors for polymer synthesis, and the design and application of functional macromolecules for biomedical applications.  This expertise included the design and application of highly active organic catalysts, the integration of these catalysts in continous flow reactors,  and the mastery of techniques to characterize the properties and biological function of the resulting materials.  Students were encouraged to develop a holistic scientific approach to devise new experimental and theoretical approaches, both on their own and through collaborative interactions, to address a central question:  how can new catalytic methods enable the synthesis of new functional and biodegradable macromolecules?  

            Intellectual Merit. This project focused on three interrelated intellectual activities: (1) the development of new families of organic catalysts that address limitations of current catalysts for the synthesis of functionalized macromolecules, (2) the development of continuous flow reactors for the programmed synthesis of block copolymer libraries, and (3)  the investigation of the functional properties of macromolecules generated with these synthetic strategies. One significant outcome of the project was the discovery of a new class of highly active and selective organic catalysts based on deprotonated  ureas.  Another significant outcome was the design and development of a new continuous flow reactor for ring-opening polymerization incorporating the hyper-active urea anion catalysts along with the development of an ?in-flow? catalyst switch strategy for accomodating monomers with different reactivities in telescoped flow reactors.

            Broader Impacts. Broader impacts the project are reflected in the degree to which the organocatalytic methods developed with NSF support by the collaborative academic/industrial team have been embraced by scientists all over the world as a mild and selective method for polymer synthesis. Three patent applications were filed on the integration of new organic catalysts into flow reactors.  The fundamental catalyst and polymer chemistry developed in this grant led to a new class of degradable materials useful for the delivery of messenger RNA; this work has been patented.  Two licensing agreements are in the final stages of negotiation on this technology illustrating the broader technological potential of these research efforts.

            The P.I.'s have actively encouraged activities in community outreach. Graduate students from the team participated in the student taught Stanford SPLASH courses to provide 7th-12th graders with the opportunity to learn about polymer science. The P.I. Waymouth hosted several high school students through Stanford?s Inspiring Future Scientists through Shadowing (IFSS) program, providing the opportunity for high school students to experience the process of research for two weeks. The research team is active in the Stanford Polymer Collective, a student-organized group that coordinates activities that include student presentations of research, tours of local industry labs, and the development of an online campus-wide instrumentation database with seminars from on-campus facilities managers to expand student access to polymer-related instrumentation. The P.I. Waymouth served as a judge along with several participants from local industries during a student poster session for the Stanford Polymer Collective.


Last Modified: 10/08/2020
Modified by: Robert M Waymouth
